courses.name: Topics in Forestry - Biological/Physical/Mathematical
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in forestry. Intended for undergraduate students.

courses.name: Topics in Forestry - Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in forestry. Intended for undergraduate students.

courses.name: Dendrology
courses.description: An introduction to the biology of trees, emphasizing identification in the field, taxonomy, ecology, geographic distribution and economic significance of forest species.

courses.name: Forest Hydrology Field Studies
courses.description: Introduction to forest hydrology, watershed management, water quantity and quality, climate and biophysical relationships.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2541, FOREST 2542, FOREST 2543, FOREST 2544 and FOREST 2545

courses.name: Forest Utilization
courses.description: Field studies of logging and milling of timber.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2540, FOREST 2542, FOREST 2543, FOREST 2544 and FOREST 2545

courses.name: Forest Measurement and Inventory
courses.description: Field measurement of standing trees including diameter, height and age. Estimation of forest timber resources using a variety of sampling schemes and techniques. Introduction to Arcview and growth models.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2540, FOREST 2541, FOREST 2543, FOREST 2544 and FOREST 2545

courses.name: Forest Ecology Field Studies
courses.description: Field studies of vegetation, soils, habitats and ecological units. Application of ecological principles of natural resource management and understanding of natural and managed forested communities with an emphasis on southeastern Missouri.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2540, FOREST 2541, FOREST 2542, FOREST 2544 and FOREST 2545

courses.name: Introduction to Silviculture and Management
courses.description: Management objectives and stand prescriptions, regeneration and intermediate silvicultural treatments, management on private and federal forest lands, tree evaluation and timber marking.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2540, FOREST 2541, FOREST 2542, FOREST 2543 and FOREST 2545

courses.name: Forest Management Planning
courses.description: Preparation and presentation of a written forest management plan using material and data developed in prerequisite courses.
courses.prerequisites: SOIL 2100, FOREST 2151Corequisites: FOREST 2540, FOREST 2541, FOREST 2542, FOREST 2543 and FOREST 2544 concurrently

courses.name: Topics in Forestry
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Intended primarily for undergraduate Forestry students. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Forest Fire Control and Use
courses.description: Fundamentals of all phases of fire protection. Objectives and techniques in use of fire.

courses.name: Forest Health and Protection
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of forest pathology and forest entomology including emphasis on ecological principles and management strategies.

courses.name: Forest Health and Protection - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of forest pathology and forest entomology including emphasis on ecological principles and management strategies.

courses.name: Fire and Society
courses.description: A study of the relationship between society (humans) and fire.  What kind of  role does fire play in day-to-day life? How has fire influenced our behavior since Day 1?  How do we view fire today?

courses.name: Wood Technology
courses.description: Structure and identification of commercial woods. Relation of growth to physical and chemical properties of wood.

courses.name: Urban Forestry
courses.description: The culture and management of trees in urban areas, including ownership patterns, species composition, growth environment, amenities provided and evaluation. One-day field trip required.

courses.name: Problems in Forestry
courses.description: Problems in Forestry

courses.name: Special Readings in Forestry
courses.description: Critical review of current literature and research in forestry, fisheries and wildlife, and methods of presenting research results.

courses.name: Topics in Forestry
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Intended for upper-division students. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Forest Ecology
courses.description: Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function.

courses.name: Forest Ecology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function.

courses.name: Practice of Silviculture
courses.description: Applied ecological principles, cultural practices, tree improvement techniques and treatments to forest stands and other lands for systematic production of goods and services.

courses.name: Tree Physiology
courses.description: Lectures on physical and chemical phenomena involved in the functions and activities of trees.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 2110, BIO_SC 1200, CHEM 1100; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Forest Economics
courses.description: Economic principles applied to production/marketing of goods and services from forest land: emphasizes capital and land factors and investment alternatives related to time.

courses.name: Photogrammetry, Inventory and Models
courses.description: Applied course in the area of aerial photogrammetry, forest inventory, and forest growth models for developing, maintaining, and utilizing these tools in a forest management.

courses.name: Logging Systems: Operations and Analyses
courses.description: A systems approach to timber harvesting from acquisition through engineering to log transport. Regional aspects and influences will be considered.

courses.name: Wildland Fire Management
courses.description: Management, administration, and organization of wildland and prescribed fires and other natural and man-made disasters. Emphasis placed on organizational arrangements of incidents rather than on either strategy or tactics.

courses.name: Forest Stand Dynamics
courses.description: Examines the development of forest structure, the role of disturbance on forest change and the use of this knowledge in applying silvicultural systems. Both forest stand dynamics theories, structure diagrams, forest growth models, and long term data sets are used to understand stand dynamics.

courses.name: Forest Resource Management
courses.description: Teaches resource managers how to develop a plan for the management of forest resources using managerial, economic, silvical and wildlife techniques for its enhancement and to meet the landowner's objectives.
courses.prerequisites: FOREST 4330 and FOREST 4350; Senior Standing only

courses.name: Agroforestry I: Theory, Practice and Adoption
courses.description: Understand biophysical, ecological, social and economic features of temperate and tropical agroforestry. Covers the basics of design, planning and implementation of agroforestry practices.

courses.name: Agroforestry Economics and Policy
courses.description: This course focuses on economic principles applied to the adoption and management of agroforestry practices at both the micro and macro scale.  This includes cost and benefits analysis of ecosystem services and marketing of goods and services from agroforestry.  More specifically, this course emphasizes both market and nonmarket valuation of managed tree and crop/livestock interactions; investment alternatives related to economics and natural resources; and decision making with relation to financial principles, environmental principles, and social principles. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: FOREST 4385 or FOREST 7385, AG_EC 1041 or permission of instructor

courses.name: Watershed Management and Water Quality
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 7390). Hydrologic processes on wildland watersheds. Effects of forest land management on streamflow, erosion and water quality.

courses.name: Forestry Internship
courses.description: Supervised professional experience with an approved public or private organization. May be repeated for credit.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Forestry Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Research apprenticeship with a faculty mentor. Students are expected to develop initial concept for the research, design experiments, collect data, and analyze data with faculty input, oversight, and guidance. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Special Readings in Forestry
courses.description: Individualized study on particular topic in forestry. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Forestry
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Intended for upper-division and graduate students. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Forest Ecology
courses.description: Principles of community, ecosystem, and population ecology and examination of the influence of environmental factors and human activity on forest dynamics, composition, structure and function.
courses.prerequisites: FOREST 2151 or BIO_SC 3210 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Practice of Silviculture
courses.description: Applied ecological principles, cultural practices, tree improvement techniques and treatments to forest stands and other lands for systematic production of goods and services.

courses.name: Tree Physiology
courses.description: Lectures on physical and chemical phenomena involved in the functions and activities of trees.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 2110; BIO_SC 1200; CHEM 1100; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Forest Economics
courses.description: Economic principles applied to production/marketing of goods and services from forest land: emphasizes capital and land factors and investment alternatives related to time.
courses.prerequisites: Mathematics requirement completed; AG_EC 1041,  or AG_EC 3080

courses.name: Photogrammetry, Inventory and Models
courses.description: Applied course in the area of aerial photogrammetry, forest inventory, and forest growth models for developing, maintaining, and utilizing these tools in a forest management.

courses.name: Logging Systems: Operations and Analysis
courses.description: A systems approach to timber harvesting from acquisition through engineering to log transport. Regional aspects and influences will be considered.

courses.name: Wildland Fire Management
courses.description: Management, administration, and organization of wildland and prescribed fires and other natural and man-made disasters. Emphasis placed on organizational arrangements of incidents rather than on either strategy or tactics.

courses.name: Forest Stand Dynamics
courses.description: Examines the development of forest structure, the role of disturbance on forest change and the use of this knowledge in applying silvicultural systems. Both forest stand dynamics theories, structure diagrams, forest growth models, and long term data sets are used to understand stand dynamics.

courses.name: Forest Resource Management
courses.description: Teaches resource managers how to develop a plan for the management of forest resources using managerial, economic, silvical and wildlife techniques for its enhancement and to meet the landowner's objectives.

courses.name: Agroforestry I: Theory, Practice and Adoption
courses.description: Understand biophysical, ecological social and economic features of temperate and tropical agroforestry. Covers the basics of design, planning and implementation of agroforestry practices.

courses.name: Watershed Management and Water Quality
courses.description: (cross-leveled with FOREST 4390). Hydrologic processes on wildland watersheds. Effects of forest land management on streamflow, erosion and water quality.

courses.name: Research in Forestry
courses.description: Original research not leading to preparation of dissertation.

courses.name: Masters Thesis Research in Forestry
courses.description: Original investigation for presentation in a M.S. thesis. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Ecological Principles of Agroforestry
courses.description: The course prepares students to develop an understanding of the complexity of agroforestry.  Students will critically analyze classical and contemporary ecological theories and apply them in designing agroforestry practices to solve complex production and environmental issues.   May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: FOREST 4385 or FOREST 7385 or permission of instructor

courses.name: Physical Hydrology
courses.description: Students will obtain an understanding of hydrologic processes in terms of the occurrence, distribution and movement of water spanning the atmosphere and lithosphere.  Students will have an opportunity to develop an understanding of physical processes governing mass and energy flux in wildland and anthropogenic systems.  May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Forestry
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Applied Silviculture
courses.description: Ecological and economic factors affecting application of silviculture in each of eighteen forest regions in United States.

courses.name: Forest Soils
courses.description: Physical, chemical and biological properties of forest soils in relation to tree growth.

courses.name: Advanced Forest Ecology
courses.description: Lecture/discussion based course emphasizing contemporary and classic ecological studies and concepts in the context of current forest ecology issues and research.

courses.name: Advanced Forest Management
courses.description: Modern quantitative methods to facilitate decision-making in harvest scheduling and regulation, land use allocation, and production planning in natural resource management.

courses.name: Advanced Forest Biometrics
courses.description: An introduction to the topics and philosophy of ecological modeling. The course will guide students through the process of developing a conceptual model, formalizing the model, formulating, parameterizing, and running the model as well as analyzing the results.

courses.name: Social Forestry
courses.description: Issues with using forestry as an international development tool; planning, implementing and evaluating farm and community forestry projects.
courses.prerequisites: FOREST 4350, or AG_EC 3270, or equivalent and instructor's consent

courses.name: Ecosystem Management: The Human Dimension
courses.description: Overview of cultural, social, political and economic dimensions of natural resource problems and issues from an ecologically grounded management perspective.

courses.name: Tree Growth-Quality Relationships
courses.description: Response of tree growth (wood formation) to such environmental influences fertilization, moisture, nutrient supply, wounding pruning, etc.

courses.name: Plant-Water Relations
courses.description: Absorption, translocation, utilization and loss of water by plants . Biophysics of water movement in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum. Effects of water deficits on physiological processes.

courses.name: Plant-Water Relations Laboratory
courses.description: Introduction to techniques and instrumentation used in studies of plant-water relations.

courses.name: Seminar in Forestry
courses.description: Discussions of current developments in Forestry, and critical study of research programs. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Dissertation Research in Forestry
courses.description: Original investigation for presentation in a doctoral dissertation. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Forestry
courses.description: Discussions of current developments in Forestry, and critical study of research programs.
